Entity-a_second_collection.description: A second collection refers to the process of reevaluating and filtering candidate rules in the context of knowledge graph completion, specifically focusing on the metrics OPSC and OPHC to ensure the quality and relevance of the rules.

Entity-automated_link_predictor.label: automated link predictor
Entity-automated_link_predictor.description: An automated link predictor is a predictive model or algorithm that generates queries for missing links in a knowledge graph by leveraging learned rules to infer relevant connections between entities.

Entity-unstructured_source.label: unstructured sources
Entity-unstructured_source.description: Unstructured sources refer to data inputs that lack a predefined format or structure, such as Wikipedia articles, which are utilized in the semi-automatic construction of Knowledge Graphs (KGs).

Entity-a_specific_target_predicate.label: a specific target predicate
Entity-a_specific_target_predicate.description: A specific target predicate refers to a particular relationship or property within a knowledge graph that is the focus of mining for high-quality Open Path (OP) rules in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-rule_with_free_variable.description: Rules with free variables refer to a specific type of function-free Horn rules that can be mined for knowledge graph completion, allowing for the inclusion of variables that are not bound to specific entities, thus enhancing the flexibility and expressiveness of the rule learning process.

Entity-specific_missing_fact.label: specific missing fact

Entity-a_pair_of_entity__e__e___(1).description: A pair of entities (e, e') refers to two specific entities in a knowledge graph that, when combined with a sequence of predicates, satisfy the conditions of an open path rule, indicating a relationship between them as defined by the rule's body.

Entity-the_entity_we_need.label: The entities we need
Entity-the_entity_we_need.description: The entities we need refer to the distinct entities in a knowledge graph that satisfy specific conditions based on the evaluation of candidate rules, specifically those that can be identified through matrix and vector operations involving the adjacency matrices of the graph.

Entity-answer_for_known_unknown.label: answers for known unknowns
Entity-answer_for_known_unknown.description: The term 'answers for known unknowns' refers to the predicted missing facts in a knowledge graph that can be inferred from existing data, specifically addressing the gaps in knowledge where the existence of certain facts is acknowledged but the specific details are not yet known.

Entity-sc.label: SC
Entity-sc.description: SC refers to a statistical measure used in the context of query generation performance evaluation, specifically indicating a minimum threshold for confidence in the queries generated by the OPRL algorithm.

Entity-link_prediction_system.label: link prediction systems
Entity-link_prediction_system.description: Link prediction systems are computational models or algorithms designed to infer the likelihood of the existence of a link or relationship between entities in a dataset, often used in knowledge graphs and social networks.

Entity-minopsc.label: MinOPSC
Entity-minopsc.description: MinOPSC is a parameter that specifies the minimum acceptable score for the quality of Open Path rules in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-e1__...__en.label: e1,...,en
Entity-e1__...__en.description: The mention 'e1,...,en' refers to the set of all entities in the knowledge graph K, represented as E, which is used in the context of evaluating candidate rules for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-maximum_rule_length.label: maximum rule length
Entity-maximum_rule_length.description: The 'maximum rule length' refers to the upper limit on the number of components or elements that can be included in a rule during the rule mining process, specifically set to 4 for the PathFinding() algorithm and extendable to 6 for the IncPathFinding() algorithm in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-body_r.label: body_r
Entity-body_r.description: body_r refers to the condition that a pair of entities (e, e') satisfies the body of a closed path rule r in a knowledge graph, meaning there exist intermediary entities that connect e and e' through a series of factual relationships represented by predicates.

Entity-p__1_.label: P(1)
Entity-p__1_.description: P(1) is a mathematical expression representing the argument embedding of the subject argument of a predicate P, calculated as the average of the embeddings of all entities that occur as subjects in the knowledge graph.

Entity-different_fact.label: different facts
Entity-different_fact.description: The term 'different facts' refers to distinct entries or relationships within a knowledge graph that can lead to the generation of the same query in the context of active knowledge graph completion.

Entity-e_7.label: e_7
Entity-e_7.description: e_7 refers to an entity that can instantiate the variable z_0 in the context of an open path rule for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-the_query.label: the query
Entity-the_query.description: The query refers to an inferred question generated from an open path rule in knowledge graph completion, specifically asking for the citizenship of an entity based on its residence.

Entity-entity_forming_the_object_argumen.label: entities forming the object argument of the tail predicate, P_n
aliases: entities forming the object argument of the tail predicate, P_n
Entity-entity_forming_the_object_argumen.description: The term 'entities forming the object argument of the tail predicate, P_n' refers to the specific entities that are linked as the output of the last predicate in an open path rule, which connects them to the entities satisfying the subject argument of the head predicate, thereby facilitating knowledge graph completion through a sequence of predicates.

mentions.local_name: entities forming the object argument of the tail predicate, P_n

Entity-evaluation___in_algorithm_1.label: Evaluation() in Algorithm 1
Entity-evaluation___in_algorithm_1.description: Evaluation() in Algorithm 1 refers to a function that assesses the quality of candidate rules for knowledge graph completion by applying specific metrics to filter out low-quality rules based on their performance against a sampled knowledge graph.

Entity-testing.label: testing
Entity-testing.description: In the context of the paper, 'testing' refers to the process of evaluating the performance of the OPRL algorithm by using a hold-out dataset, where 10% of the data is reserved for assessing the quality of the mined rules.

Entity-f1.label: F1
Entity-f1.description: F1 refers to a performance measure used to evaluate the accuracy of queries in terms of precision and recall in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-the_original_tail.label: the original tail
Entity-the_original_tail.description: The original tail refers to the concluding part of a rule in the context of knowledge graph completion, which can be extended by appending additional predicates to form a more comprehensive rule.

Entity-association_rule_mining.label: association rule mining
Entity-association_rule_mining.description: Association rule mining is a data mining technique used to discover interesting relationships and patterns among a set of items in large datasets.

Entity-p2__z0__z1_.label: P2(z0,z1)
Entity-p2__z0__z1_.description: P2(z0,z1) refers to a predicate in the context of an Open Path rule that connects two entities z0 and z1 within a knowledge graph, indicating a relationship that is part of the rule's body for evaluating the rule's satisfiability.

Entity-the_subject_argument_of_p_t.label: the subject argument of P_t
Entity-the_subject_argument_of_p_t.description: The subject argument of P_t refers to the set of entities that serve as the subject in the predicate P_t within the context of knowledge graph completion, where its embedding is calculated by averaging the embeddings of all entities that appear as subjects in the predicate.

Entity-genuinely_missing_fact.label: genuinely missing facts
Entity-genuinely_missing_fact.description: Genuinely missing facts refer to actual pieces of information that are absent from a knowledge graph, which, if present, would affect the evaluation of query relevance and the accuracy of precision and recall metrics in knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-compositional-based_embedding_lea.label: compositional-based embedding learner
Entity-compositional-based_embedding_lea.description: The compositional-based embedding learner refers to RESCAL, an algorithm that embeds entities and predicates into a latent space using weight matrices for predicates and vectors for entities, enabling the capture of complex interactions for knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-predicate_p_k.label: predicate P_k
Entity-predicate_p_k.description: predicate P_k refers to a mathematical object represented as a matrix in the context of knowledge graph embeddings, specifically used in the RESCAL model to capture interactions between entities and predicates.

Entity-tail.label: tail
Entity-tail.description: In the context of rule learning for knowledge graph completion, 'tail' refers to the part of a rule that is appended to the body of the rule, which typically represents the conclusion or outcome of the rule's logical structure.

Entity-ei.label: ei
Entity-ei.description: The mention 'ei' refers to a variable representing an entity in the knowledge graph that satisfies specific conditions related to the evaluation of candidate rules in the context of the proposed algorithm for active knowledge graph completion.

Entity-massive_quantity_of_weakly-struct.label: massive quantities of weakly-structured data
Entity-massive_quantity_of_weakly-struct.description: Massive quantities of weakly-structured data refer to large volumes of information that lack a rigid organizational framework, making them suitable for representation in Knowledge Graphs, which allow for flexible data integration and querying.

Entity-the_following_two_relevant_query.label: the following two relevant queries
Entity-the_following_two_relevant_query.description: The term 'the following two relevant queries' refers to specific queries generated from a known-missing fact in a knowledge graph, exemplified by 'presidentOf(?, USA)' and 'presidentOf(Obama, ?)', which are used to guide link predictors in identifying and completing missing information in the graph.

Entity-link_between_the_variable.label: links between the variables
Entity-link_between_the_variable.description: The term 'links between the variables' refers to the connections established in a closed path rule within a knowledge graph, where a sequence of predicates relates a set of variables in a manner that allows for the inference of new facts based on existing relationships.

Entity-e_0t.label: E_0^T
Entity-e_0t.description: E_0^T represents the embedding vector of the entity e0 in the scoring function used to evaluate the plausibility of a fact in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-z_i__1__i__n_-_1_.label: z_i (1 ≤ i ≤ n - 1)
Entity-z_i__1__i__n_-_1_.description: The term 'z_i (1 ≤ i ≤ n - 1)' refers to a variable representing entities in an open path (OP) rule, specifically serving as the object argument of the predicate P_i and the subject argument of the subsequent predicate P_{i+1} within a sequence of predicates that connect entities in a knowledge graph.

Entity-p_2.label: P_2
Entity-p_2.description: P_2 refers to a binary predicate in the context of knowledge graphs, representing a relationship between two entities in a fact expressed as an RDF triple.

Entity-the_embeddings_of_all_the_entity_.label: the embeddings of all the entities in the argument position
aliases: the embeddings of all the entities in the argument position
Entity-the_embeddings_of_all_the_entity_.description: The embeddings of all the entities in the argument position refer to the vector representations derived by averaging the embeddings of entities that serve as arguments in a predicate within a knowledge graph.

mentions.local_name: the embeddings of all the entities in the argument position

Entity-each.label: Each
Entity-each.description: Each refers to a closed path (CP) rule in rule-based knowledge graph completion, which consists of a head and a body that together form a logical implication.

Entity-definition_1.label: Definition 1
Entity-definition_1.description: Definition 1 defines the concept of 'satisfaction' and 'support' in the context of closed path (CP) rules, specifying the conditions under which a pair of entities satisfies the body and head of a CP rule in a knowledge graph.

Entity-z.label: z
Entity-z.description: In the context of open path rules for knowledge graph completion, 'z' represents a bound variable that is used to denote an entity in the body of the rule, specifically indicating a location where another entity 'x' resides.

Entity-candidate.label: candidates
Entity-candidate.description: In the context of the paper, 'candidates' refers to the potential rules generated during the PathFinding() process that are being filtered based on their quality for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-definition_6.label: Definition 6
Entity-definition_6.description: Definition 6 refers to the co-occurrence fitness function, which quantifies the quality of an open path rule by summing the local co-occurrence fitness values of its predicates.

Entity-a__pk_.label: A(Pk)
Entity-a__pk_.description: A(Pk) refers to a binary adjacency matrix representation of the knowledge graph, where the (i, j)th element indicates the presence (1) or absence (0) of the fact Pk(ei, ej) in the set of facts F.

Entity-each_predicate_p_k.label: each predicate P_k
Entity-each_predicate_p_k.description: Each predicate P_k refers to a matrix representation of a binary relation in a knowledge graph, capturing the interactions between entities in a latent feature space as part of the RESCAL embedding method.

Entity-vector.label: vectors
Entity-vector.description: In the context of knowledge graph completion, 'vectors' refer to mathematical representations of predicates in a low-dimensional space used for scoring and inferring relationships between entities.

Entity-e_3.label: e_3
Entity-e_3.description: e_3 is one of the three entities that can instantiate the variable z_0 in the context of an open path rule for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-top-ranked_candidate.label: top-ranked candidates
Entity-top-ranked_candidate.description: The term 'top-ranked candidates' refers to the high-quality candidate rules generated during the IncPathFinding() process, which are selected based on their potential effectiveness in extending existing rules for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-p__2_.label: P(2)
Entity-p__2_.description: P(2) refers to the argument embedding vector for the object arguments of a predicate P in a knowledge graph, calculated as the average of the embeddings of all entities occurring as objects of P.

Entity-body_atom.label: body atoms
Entity-body_atom.description: Body atoms refer to the components of logical rules in knowledge graph completion that are used to determine the satisfiability of candidate rules by checking the relationships between entities in the graph.

Entity-industrial_application.label: industrial application
Entity-industrial_application.description: The term 'industrial application' refers to the practical use of a link prediction model within a business or organizational context, specifically in generating relevant queries from a knowledge graph to enhance active knowledge graph completion.

Entity-an_instantiation_of_the_body_of_a.label: an instantiation of the body of an OP rule
aliases: an instantiation of the body of an OP rule
Entity-an_instantiation_of_the_body_of_a.description: An instantiation of the body of an OP rule refers to a specific assignment of values to the variables in the body of an Open Path rule, which allows for the generation of a query rather than a definitive fact.

mentions.local_name: an instantiation of the body of an OP rule

Entity-the_latter_embeddings.label: the latter embeddings
Entity-the_latter_embeddings.description: The latter embeddings refer to the compact representations of entities and predicates learned by certain embedding methods, which, while beneficial for link prediction tasks, are deemed less effective for the heuristic function employed in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-a_number_of_entity.label: a number of entities
Entity-a_number_of_entity.description: The term 'a number of entities' refers to a collection of entities that are directly related to a specific target predicate within a knowledge graph, which are utilized to form a reduced graph for the purpose of mining high-quality Open Path rules.

Entity-key_constraint.label: key constraints
Entity-key_constraint.description: Key constraints refer to the structural rules in relational databases that enforce data integrity by ensuring that certain fields are unique and not null, contrasting with the more flexible nature of knowledge graphs.

Entity-entity__e__e__.label: entities (e, e')
Entity-entity__e__e__.description: The mention 'entities (e, e')' refers to a pair of identifiers representing objects in a knowledge graph, where 'e' is the subject entity and 'e'' is the object entity, used in the context of rule-based knowledge graph completion to evaluate the satisfaction of a rule's body and head.

Entity-rule_learning_in_inductive_logic_.label: rule learning in inductive logic programming
aliases: rule learning in inductive logic programming
Entity-rule_learning_in_inductive_logic_.description: Rule learning in inductive logic programming is a methodology that focuses on deriving rules from data using logical inference techniques to facilitate knowledge representation and decision-making.

mentions.local_name: rule learning in inductive logic programming

Entity-output.label: outputs
Entity-output.description: The term 'outputs' refers to the results generated by the OPRL and RLvLR* systems in the context of query performance comparison using ROC curves.

Entity-specific_link_predictor.label: specific link predictor
Entity-specific_link_predictor.description: A specific link predictor refers to a particular algorithm or model used to predict links in a knowledge graph by ranking potential entities that could complete a given query, although the paper does not utilize any specific link predictor for answering questions.

Entity-this_aggregation.label: This aggregation
Entity-this_aggregation.description: This aggregation refers to the method used in the RLvLR system, specifically the Noisy-OR operator that combines multiple high-performing rules to predict facts, which is deemed unsuitable for the query generation task where prioritizing the top prediction is essential.

Entity-p.label: P
Entity-p.description: P refers to a predicate in a knowledge graph, represented as a weight matrix that captures the relationships between entities through its subject and object arguments.

Entity-entity.label: entities
Entity-entity.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, 'entities' refer to the individual items or objects that are represented within the graph, which can include people, places, concepts, or any identifiable data points that have relationships with one another.

Entity-link_prediction.label: link prediction
Entity-link_prediction.description: Link prediction is a machine learning task that involves predicting the existence of relationships or connections between entities in a dataset, often used in the context of knowledge graphs and social networks.

Entity-e0.label: e0
Entity-e0.description: e0 refers to an entity in a knowledge graph that is involved in a fact represented by the predicate P1, and its connection to another entity e1 is evaluated using a scoring function based on their embeddings.

Entity-f_coo__r_.label: f_coo (r)
Entity-f_coo__r_.description: f_coo (r) is a mathematical function that calculates the co-occurrence fitness of an open path rule by summing the local fitness values of predicate pairs along the rule's path.

Entity-latent__unnamed_feature.label: latent, unnamed features
Entity-latent__unnamed_feature.description: Latent, unnamed features refer to the intrinsic properties and relationships of entities and predicates in a knowledge graph that are represented in a low-dimensional vector space, which are not explicitly defined in the graph's vocabulary but are utilized for tasks such as predicting new facts and enhancing rule learning.

Entity-obsolete_and_low-quality_rule.label: obsolete and low-quality rules
Entity-obsolete_and_low-quality_rule.description: Obsolete and low-quality rules refer to outdated or ineffective rules within the context of knowledge graph completion that do not contribute meaningfully to the accuracy or efficiency of the rule evaluation process.

Entity-ophc__0.01.label: OPHC > 0.01
Entity-ophc__0.01.description: OPHC > 0.01 refers to a quality metric threshold indicating that only rules with an Open Path Rule Quality score greater than 0.01 are considered for inclusion in the evaluation of the OPRL algorithm's performance.

Entity-their_relation.label: their relations
Entity-their_relation.description: The term 'their relations' refers to the connections or associations between entities within a knowledge graph, which are represented as intrinsic properties that can be utilized in the context of representation learning for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-the_plausibility_of_the_fact_that.label: the plausibility of the fact that e0 is connected to e1 via predicate P1
aliases: the plausibility of the fact that e0 is connected to e1 via predicate P1
Entity-the_plausibility_of_the_fact_that.description: The term refers to a scoring function that quantifies the likelihood of a connection between two entities, e0 and e1, through a specific predicate P1 within the context of knowledge graph completion.

mentions.local_name: the plausibility of the fact that e0 is connected to e1 via predicate P1

Entity-a_method.label: a method
Entity-a_method.description: The term 'a method' refers to a computational approach used to check the satisfiability of body atoms in candidate rules for evaluating the quality of Open Path rules in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-chain_of_predicate.label: chain of predicates
Entity-chain_of_predicate.description: The 'chain of predicates' refers to a sequence of logical relationships represented by predicates in an open path rule that connects entities through their subject and object arguments, facilitating knowledge graph completion.

Entity-a_missing_fact.label: a missing fact
Entity-a_missing_fact.description: A missing fact refers to a specific piece of information that is not present in a knowledge graph (KG) but can be inferred or identified as necessary for the completeness of the KG, even in the absence of a clear pattern or rule that would typically allow for its instantiation.

Entity-fitness_value_of_rule.label: fitness values of rules
Entity-fitness_value_of_rule.description: The term 'fitness values of rules' refers to the quantitative assessments derived from specific fitness functions that evaluate the quality of generated rules in the context of knowledge graph completion, allowing for the selection of the most promising rules based on their estimated effectiveness.

Entity-each_non-zero_element_of_this_vec.label: Each non-zero element of this vector
aliases: Each non-zero element of this vector
Entity-each_non-zero_element_of_this_vec.description: Each non-zero element of this vector represents an entity that satisfies a specific condition in the context of knowledge graph rule evaluation, indicating the presence of distinct entities related to the rule's head.

mentions.local_name: Each non-zero element of this vector
Each non-zero element of this vector

Entity-run_time_in_hour.label: run times in hours
Entity-run_time_in_hour.description: Run times in hours refers to the average duration, measured in hours, taken to execute processes or algorithms related to the mining of quality rules from knowledge graphs in the context of the OPRL method.

Entity-it.label: it
Entity-it.description: The term 'it' refers to the YAGO2 knowledge graph, which is suspected to induce fewer rules and exhibit weaker performance due to its weak structure or a higher number of missing facts.

Entity-quality_of_each_rule.label: quality of each rule
Entity-quality_of_each_rule.description: The 'quality of each rule' refers to a measure used to assess the effectiveness and relevance of candidate rules in the context of knowledge graph completion, specifically evaluated through an efficient method involving matrix and vector operations.

Entity-satisfying_entity_e2_and_e3.label: satisfying entities e2 and e3
Entity-satisfying_entity_e2_and_e3.description: The term 'satisfying entities e2 and e3' refers to the distinct entities in a knowledge graph that fulfill the conditions of a specific rule's head and body, indicating that both entities can be linked through the predicates defined in the graph.

Entity-the_complexity_of_the_learning_ph.label: the complexity of the learning phase
aliases: the complexity of the learning phase
Entity-the_complexity_of_the_learning_ph.description: The complexity of the learning phase refers to the computational and algorithmic challenges involved in efficiently mining and evaluating open path rules from knowledge graphs, while managing the scalability and quality of the learning process.

mentions.local_name: the complexity of the learning phase
the complexity of the learning phase

Entity-the_target_predicate__p_1.label: the target predicate, P_1
Entity-the_target_predicate__p_1.description: The target predicate, P_1, refers to a specific relation or function within a knowledge graph that connects entities, used in the context of generating queries for active knowledge graph completion.

Entity-4.description: The mention '4' refers to the maximum rule length parameter set for the PathFinding() algorithm in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-information.label: information
Entity-information.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, 'information' refers to the data or knowledge that can be added to the graph in a flexible manner, enabling the representation of relationships and entities without strict structural constraints.

Entity-e_9.label: e_9
Entity-e_9.description: e_9 refers to an entity in the knowledge graph that can instantiate the variable z_0 to satisfy the body part of an open path rule.

Entity-similarity_fitness_function.label: similarity fitness function
Entity-similarity_fitness_function.description: The similarity fitness function is a mathematical function used to evaluate the quality of rules in knowledge graph completion by measuring the degree of similarity between the head and body predicates based on their associated entities.

Entity-the_new_body.label: the new body
Entity-the_new_body.description: The new body refers to an additional sequence of predicates that is appended to the tail of an existing rule in the context of generating Open Path rules for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-test_fact.label: test facts
Entity-test_fact.description: Test facts refer to specific pieces of information that are intentionally withheld from a knowledge graph during the evaluation of link prediction models, serving as a benchmark for assessing the model's ability to rediscover these missing facts.

Entity-embedding_the_entity_and_predicat.label: embedding the entities and predicates
Entity-embedding_the_entity_and_predicat.description: The phrase 'embedding the entities and predicates' refers to the process of representing the entities and predicates of a knowledge graph in a low-dimensional latent space to facilitate tasks such as link prediction and knowledge graph reconstruction.

Entity-additive_calculus.label: additive calculus
Entity-additive_calculus.description: Additive calculus refers to a mathematical operation used in translation-based embeddings to represent predicates as vectors for scoring in knowledge graph completion.

Entity-100__hc_and_sc.label: 100% HC and SC
Entity-100__hc_and_sc.description: 100% HC and SC refers to a condition in rule learning for knowledge graphs where a rule explains every fact related to its head and is completely redundant with respect to the knowledge graph, indicating perfect head coverage and standard confidence.

Entity-the_product_of_the_entity_and_pre.label: the product of the entity and predicate embeddings
aliases: the product of the entity and predicate embeddings
Entity-the_product_of_the_entity_and_pre.description: The product of the entity and predicate embeddings refers to the mathematical operation that combines the vector representations of entities and the matrix representations of predicates in the RESCAL model, which is used to capture interactions between entities and predicates for knowledge graph completion.

mentions.local_name: the product of the entity and predicate embeddings

Entity-co-occurrence_of_z_0.label: co-occurrences of z_0
Entity-co-occurrence_of_z_0.description: The term 'co-occurrences of z_0' refers to the instances where the variable z_0 appears as the object argument of a predicate P_t and as the subject argument of another predicate P_1 within the context of open path rules in knowledge graph completion, indicating a relationship between entities that enhances the quality of the rules being evaluated.

Entity-link-based_clustering.label: link-based clustering
Entity-link-based_clustering.description: Link-based clustering is a method in representation learning that organizes entities in a knowledge graph based on the relationships and connections between them, facilitating tasks such as link prediction and entity resolution.

Entity-entity_satisfying_the_subject_arg.label: entities satisfying the subject argument of the head predicate, P_t
aliases: entities satisfying the subject argument of the head predicate, P_t
Entity-entity_satisfying_the_subject_arg.description: The term 'entities satisfying the subject argument of the head predicate, P_t' refers to the specific entities that fulfill the subject role in the context of a given predicate P_t within an open path rule, which connects these entities to others through a sequence of predicates in a knowledge graph.

mentions.local_name: entities satisfying the subject argument of the head predicate, P_t

Entity-program.label: program
Entity-program.description: In the context of knowledge graph completion, a 'program' refers specifically to a television program that is used in rule-based queries to infer information about its participants and presenters.

Entity-the_test_set.label: the test set
Entity-the_test_set.description: The test set refers to a subset of data used to evaluate the performance of the OPRL algorithm by providing a reference for determining the relevance of generated queries, specifically containing instances that are not present in the training set.

Entity-p1__...__pm.label: P1,...,Pm
Entity-p1__...__pm.description: P1,...,Pm refers to the set of all predicates in the knowledge graph K, which is defined as K = (E,F) where F contains the predicates used to represent relationships between entities in the set E.

Entity-rule-based_link_predictor.label: rule-based link predictor
Entity-rule-based_link_predictor.description: A rule-based link predictor is a computational model that utilizes predefined rules to infer the likelihood of connections or relationships between entities in a network.

Entity-massive_size.label: massive size
Entity-massive_size.description: The term 'massive size' refers to the large scale of the knowledge graphs (KGs) that the baseline query generator Prand is unable to process due to their extensive volume of data.

Entity-erroneous_fact.label: erroneous facts
Entity-erroneous_fact.description: Erroneous facts refer to incorrect or misleading information that is asserted during the construction of knowledge graphs, which can lead to incomplete or inaccurate representations of data.

Entity-inference.label: inference
Entity-inference.description: Inference refers to the process of deriving specific missing facts from a knowledge graph using closed rules, which predict facts based on existing relationships and entities.

Entity-relevant.label: relevant
Entity-relevant.description: The term 'relevant' refers to the necessity for queries in knowledge graph completion to be pertinent and useful in identifying missing facts or guiding link predictors.

Entity-extension_to_6.label: extension to 6
Entity-extension_to_6.description: The 'extension to 6' refers to a parameter in the IncPathFinding() method that allows the maximum rule length to be increased from 4 to 6 during the process of mining rules for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-head_instance.label: head instances
Entity-head_instance.description: Head instances refer to the target pairs of entities in a knowledge graph that satisfy the head of a closed path rule, indicating the facts that can be inferred from the rule.

Entity-instantiation.label: instantiation
Entity-instantiation.description: In the context of knowledge graph completion, 'instantiation' refers to the specific assignment of values to the variables in a rule, allowing the rule to be applied to particular entities within the graph.

Entity-a_previously_unstudied_direction.label: a previously unstudied direction
Entity-a_previously_unstudied_direction.description: The term 'a previously unstudied direction' refers to the novel approach in knowledge graph completion that focuses on identifying and introducing missing entities into the knowledge graph, rather than merely predicting known missing facts.

Entity-entity_that_are_related_to_the_ex.label: entities that are related to the existing entities
aliases: entities that are related to the existing entities
Entity-entity_that_are_related_to_the_ex.description: The term 'entities that are related to the existing entities' refers to additional entities that are incorporated into a knowledge graph by identifying and including those that are connected to already selected entities through various predicates, thereby expanding the set of relevant entities for further analysis and rule mining.

mentions.local_name: entities that are related to the existing entities

Entity-set_of_entity.label: set of entities
Entity-set_of_entity.description: The 'set of entities' refers to the collection of potential answers that a link predictor attempts to rank in response to a query, which may include both existing and non-existing entities within the knowledge graph.

Entity-_p__a_.label: (P, A)
Entity-_p__a_.description: The mention (P, A) refers to the tuple representing the target predicate P and its associated argument embeddings computed from the reduced knowledge graph K'.

Entity-weakly_structured.label: weakly structured
Entity-weakly_structured.description: The term 'weakly structured' refers to a characteristic of a knowledge graph that indicates a lack of clear, repeatable patterns or relationships among its entities, which may contribute to its incompleteness and the presence of missing facts.

Entity-comparative_value.label: comparative value
Entity-comparative_value.description: Comparative value refers to the assessment of the relative importance or relevance of generated queries in the context of knowledge graph completion, particularly in determining which queries are more likely to yield useful information for enhancing the knowledge graph.

Entity-the_validity_of_our_test_set.label: the validity of our test set
aliases: the validity of our test set
Entity-the_validity_of_our_test_set.description: The validity of our test set refers to the reliability and accuracy of the test set used in the evaluation of the OPRL algorithm, particularly concerning how missing facts are classified, which can impact the precision and recall metrics of the generated queries.

mentions.local_name: the validity of our test set

Entity-confidence_degree__cd_.label: confidence degree (CD)
aliases: the confidence degree (CD) of such a query
Entity-confidence_degree__cd_.description: The confidence degree (CD) is a metric that quantifies the reliability of a query in active knowledge graph completion by taking the maximum observed predictive score (OPSC) from all rules that can induce the query, excluding any contributions from redundant rules.

mentions.local_name: the confidence degree (CD) of such a query

Entity-a_query_(1).label: a query
Entity-a_query_(1).description: A query refers to a specific question or request for information posed to a knowledge graph, aimed at uncovering missing facts or entities, which can be answered by a link predictor that ranks potential answers.

Entity-0.59.description: 0.59 refers to the OPSC (Open Path Score) value associated with the rule indicating that if a participant in a TV program is known along with their occupation, it is likely that the presenter of the program is also known.

Entity-p1__x__z0_.label: P1(x,z0)
Entity-p1__x__z0_.description: P1(x,z0) is a predicate in the context of an Open Path rule that defines a relationship between the variables x and z0, which is derived from the conjunction of other predicates P2 and P3 in the knowledge graph.

Entity-f.label: F
Entity-f.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, 'F' refers to the collection of facts that form the foundational data structure of the graph, represented as pairs of entities and their relationships.

Entity-link_predictor.label: link predictors
Entity-link_predictor.description: Link predictors are algorithms or models used in machine learning to forecast the existence of relationships or connections between entities in a dataset, particularly in the context of knowledge graphs.

Entity-p4__z2__z3_.label: P4(z2, z3)
Entity-p4__z2__z3_.description: P4(z2, z3) refers to a predicate in the context of the Open Path rule mining process, where it represents a relationship between the entities z2 and z3 within a knowledge graph.

Entity-the_more_probable_fact.label: the more probable facts
Entity-the_more_probable_fact.description: The more probable facts refer to the subset of data within a knowledge graph that are deemed more likely to be relevant for improving predictions in link prediction tasks, as opposed to irrelevant facts that are filtered out.

Entity-fb15kse.label: FB15KSE
Entity-fb15kse.description: FB15KSE is a benchmark dataset used for evaluating knowledge graph completion and related tasks.

Entity-known-missing_fact.label: known-missing fact
Entity-known-missing_fact.description: The term 'known-missing fact' refers to a specific fact that is recognized as absent from a knowledge graph, which can be used to generate relevant queries for knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-fact_about_the_target_predicate.label: facts about the target predicate
Entity-fact_about_the_target_predicate.description: The mention 'facts about the target predicate' refers to the specific instances or data points related to a named predicate P_1 in the context of knowledge graph completion, which are used to generate relevant queries for active knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-p_h__e__e__.label: P_h(e, e')
Entity-p_h__e__e__.description: P_h(e, e') refers to the predicate in the head of a closed path rule that asserts a relationship between the entities e and e' in a knowledge graph, indicating that the fact P_h(e, e') is true within that graph.

Entity-e1.label: e1
Entity-e1.description: e1 refers to an entity involved in a target predicate P_t within a knowledge graph, where it is paired with another entity e2 in a fact representation.

Entity-cd__q_.label: CD(q)
Entity-cd__q_.description: CD(q) refers to the confidence degree of a query q, defined as the maximum OPSC (Open Path Score Confidence) of all the rules that can induce the query from a given knowledge graph.

Entity-various_method.label: Various methods
Entity-various_method.description: Various methods refer to the different approaches and techniques developed for constructing embeddings in the context of knowledge graph completion, specifically including translation-based and compositional embeddings.

Entity-_0_0_2___0_2_1___1_0_0_.description: The entity '| 0 0 2 | | 0 2 1 | | 1 0 0 |' represents the result of a matrix multiplication of two adjacency matrices A(P1) and A(P2) in the context of knowledge graph evaluation, indicating the connections between entities based on the predicates defined in the graph.

Entity-the_proportion_of_the_inferred_he.label: the proportion of the inferred head instances
aliases: the proportion of the inferred head instances
Entity-the_proportion_of_the_inferred_he.description: The proportion of the inferred head instances refers to the measure of how many of the instances that can be inferred as true by a rule's body also satisfy the rule's head within a knowledge graph, indicating the rule's reliability and effectiveness in capturing valid relationships.

mentions.local_name: the proportion of the inferred head instances

Entity-fact_p_1__e0__e1_.label: fact P_1(e0, e1)
Entity-fact_p_1__e0__e1_.description: The term 'fact P_1(e0, e1)' refers to a specific relationship or connection between two entities, e0 and e1, represented by the predicate P_1, which is evaluated using a scoring function that measures the plausibility of this connection based on their embeddings in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-the_body_of_each_rule.label: the body of each rule
Entity-the_body_of_each_rule.description: The body of each rule refers to the set of conditions or premises in a rule that, when satisfied, can lead to the generation of a query for knowledge graph completion, even if the conclusion or head of the rule cannot be fully instantiated.

Entity-participant__z__w_.label: participant(z, w)
Entity-participant__z__w_.description: The term 'participant(z, w)' refers to a rule in the context of knowledge graph completion, indicating that if there is a TV program (z) that has a participant (w) with a specific occupation (y), then it is likely that the presenter of the program (x) is also known.

Entity-ranked_sequence.label: ranked sequence
Entity-ranked_sequence.description: The term 'ranked sequence' refers to a list of entities ordered by their relevance or likelihood of being correct answers to a query in the context of knowledge graph completion, where multiple potential answers are provided rather than a single definitive answer.

Entity-ranked_sequence_of_answer.label: ranked sequence of answers
Entity-ranked_sequence_of_answer.description: The 'ranked sequence of answers' refers to the output format used by link predictors in knowledge graph completion, where multiple potential answers are provided in order of relevance, rather than a single definitive answer.

Entity-aggregation.label: aggregation
Entity-aggregation.description: In this context, 'aggregation' refers to the method of combining multiple high-performing rules in the RLvLR system, specifically using a Noisy-OR operator, which is deemed incompatible with the task of generating queries that prioritize only the top prediction.

Entity-the_rule_body.label: the rule body
Entity-the_rule_body.description: The rule body refers to the part of a rule in rule-based knowledge graph completion that consists of predicates and variables, which must be satisfied in order to infer a corresponding fact represented by the rule's head.

Entity-a_matrix_of_binary_value.label: a matrix of binary values
Entity-a_matrix_of_binary_value.description: A matrix of binary values is a square n × n representation of a knowledge graph where each element indicates the presence (1) or absence (0) of a specific fact between pairs of entities, facilitating the evaluation of candidate rules in knowledge graph completion.

Entity-the_first_argument.label: the first argument
Entity-the_first_argument.description: The first argument refers to the initial position in a rule's head or body within the context of evaluating candidate rules for knowledge graph completion, specifically indicating the entities that satisfy the conditions of the rule.

Entity-fb15k_selected.label: FB15K SELECTED
Entity-fb15k_selected.description: FB15K SELECTED, also referred to as FB15KSE, is a dataset derived from Freebase that is commonly used as a benchmark for evaluating link prediction algorithms in knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-argument_position.label: argument positions
Entity-argument_position.description: In the context of knowledge graph completion, 'argument positions' refer to the specific roles that entities play within predicates, where each predicate has a subject argument in the first position and an object argument in the second position, which are essential for defining the relationships between entities in the graph.

Entity-query_of_unclear_origin.label: queries of unclear origin
Entity-query_of_unclear_origin.description: Queries of unclear origin refer to inquiries used in knowledge graph completion that are typically derived from a holdback test set in experimental settings, aimed at addressing gaps in the knowledge graph.

Entity-this_last_step.label: This last step
Entity-this_last_step.description: This last step refers to the iterative process of expanding a set of entities related to a target predicate in the knowledge graph, which is performed multiple times based on the maximum length of the target rules.

Entity-several_direction_for_future_rese.label: several directions for future research
Entity-several_direction_for_future_rese.description: The term 'several directions for future research' refers to the proposed avenues for further investigation and development in the area of existential rule learning within knowledge graph completion, as outlined by the authors in their paper.

Entity-modified_leading-edge_link_predic.label: modified leading-edge link predictor
Entity-modified_leading-edge_link_predic.description: The modified leading-edge link predictor is a variant of a link prediction algorithm that has been adjusted to enhance its performance in generating relevant queries for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-query_that_can_be_answered_from_t.label: queries that can be answered from the training set
aliases: queries that can be answered from the training set
Entity-query_that_can_be_answered_from_t.description: The phrase 'queries that can be answered from the training set' refers to those queries whose answers are already included in the training data used for knowledge graph completion, and thus are not considered relevant for evaluating the performance of the query generation method being discussed.

mentions.local_name: queries that can be answered from the training set

Entity-initial_set_of_fact.label: initial set of facts
Entity-initial_set_of_fact.description: The 'initial set of facts' refers to the foundational data or information that a system, such as CHAI, relies on to filter and improve the prediction of link predictors in the knowledge graph completion process.

Entity-a_set_of_entity__country_.label: a set of entities (countries)
Entity-a_set_of_entity__country_.description: The term 'a set of entities (countries)' refers to a collection of sovereign states that may be considered as potential answers to queries generated in the context of knowledge graph completion, particularly when the specific answer is unknown or absent from the knowledge graph.

Entity-a_relevant_query_(1).label: a relevant query
Entity-a_relevant_query_(1).description: A relevant query refers to a query generated when the body of a rule is instantiated but lacks sufficient facts to fully instantiate the head of the rule, thereby indicating a potential missing entity in the knowledge graph.

Entity-rightmost_predicate.label: rightmost predicate
Entity-rightmost_predicate.description: The 'rightmost predicate' refers to the last predicate in a sequence of predicates that form the body of an Open Path (OP) rule being generated during the knowledge graph completion process.

Entity-each_row.label: each row
Entity-each_row.description: In the context of the paper, 'each row' refers to the individual rows of an adjacency matrix representation of a knowledge graph, where each row corresponds to a specific entity and is used to compute the number of distinct entities satisfying certain conditions in the evaluation of candidate rules.

Entity-relationship.label: relationships
Entity-relationship.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, 'relationships' refer to the connections or associations between entities that are recorded within the graph, which are crucial for understanding the structure and semantics of the data represented.

Entity-tail_predicate.label: tail predicate
Entity-tail_predicate.description: The 'tail predicate' refers to the final predicate in an Open Path (OP) rule that connects entities through a sequence of predicates, specifically serving as the object argument in the rule's structure.

Entity-two_cp_rule.label: two CP rules
Entity-two_cp_rule.description: The term 'two CP rules' refers to the two closed path rules that can be derived as logical consequences from a single open path rule by unifying the free variable with a variable in the head of the rule.

Entity-the_body_(1).label: the body
Entity-the_body_(1).description: In the context of knowledge graph completion, 'the body' refers to the set of conditions or predicates that must be satisfied by pairs of entities in order to validate a rule within the graph.

Entity-existence_of_missing_fact.label: existence of missing facts
Entity-existence_of_missing_fact.description: The 'existence of missing facts' refers to the identification of facts that are not currently represented in a knowledge graph, even when the entities related to those facts may not be present in the graph.

Entity-baseline_query_generator.label: baseline query generator
Entity-baseline_query_generator.description: The baseline query generator, referred to as Prand, is a software tool that generates query sets for knowledge graph completion by randomly selecting predicates and assigning subject or object entities based on their proportions in a test set.

Entity-the_two_set_of_embeddings.label: the two sets of embeddings
Entity-the_two_set_of_embeddings.description: The two sets of embeddings refer to the entity vectors {e_i} and predicate matrices {P_k} learned by the RESCAL model, which are used to represent entities and predicates in a latent space for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-i.label: i
Entity-i.description: The variable 'i' represents an index in a sequence of predicates within the context of open path rules, indicating the position of a predicate in the chain of predicates that connect entities in a knowledge graph.

Entity-learning_system.label: learning system
Entity-learning_system.description: The 'learning system' refers to a parameterized component within the algorithm that is responsible for tuning the selection of top candidate rules based on their fitness values in the context of knowledge graph completion.

Entity-roc_curve.label: ROC curves
Entity-roc_curve.description: ROC curves are graphical representations used to evaluate the performance of a binary classification model by plotting the true positive rate against the false positive rate at various threshold settings.

Entity-a_matrix_p_k____dd_.label: a matrix P_k ∈ ℝ^{d×d}
Entity-a_matrix_p_k____dd_.description: The matrix P_k ∈ ℝ^{d×d} represents the embedding of a predicate in a knowledge graph, capturing the relationships between entities in a latent feature space of dimensionality d.

Entity-freebase.label: Freebase
Entity-freebase.description: Freebase is a large collaborative knowledge base consisting of structured data, which serves as a dataset for various knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-_e__e__.label: (e, e')
Entity-_e__e__.description: (e, e') refers to a pair of entities in a knowledge graph that are used to evaluate whether a specific rule's head is satisfied by the relationship defined by the predicate P_h.

Entity-structural_constraint.label: structural constraints
Entity-structural_constraint.description: Structural constraints refer to the minimal limitations imposed on the organization and addition of information within Knowledge Graphs, allowing for a more flexible and less rigid data structure compared to traditional relational databases.

Entity-predicate.label: predicate
Entity-predicate.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, a 'predicate' refers to a binary relation or property that connects two entities in an RDF triple, indicating how the subject entity is related to the object entity.

Entity-performance.label: performance
Entity-performance.description: In this context, 'performance' refers to the effectiveness and reliability of link predictors in providing ranked sequences of answers to queries in knowledge graph completion tasks.

Entity-query_generation_task.label: query generation task
Entity-query_generation_task.description: The query generation task is a computational task focused on creating queries that can effectively retrieve relevant information from databases or search engines.

Entity-triple.label: triple
Entity-triple.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, a 'triple' refers to a data representation consisting of three components: a subject, a predicate, and an object, which together express a specific relationship or fact about entities within the graph.

Entity-type.label: type
Entity-type.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, 'type' refers to the structural constraints that define the nature of data entries, such as the classification of entities and their relationships, which are less rigid compared to those in relational databases.

Entity-a_pair_of_entity__e__e__.description: A pair of entities (e, e') refers to two specific entities in a knowledge graph that together satisfy the conditions of a rule's body by establishing a series of factual relationships through predicates.

Entity-first_argument.description: The 'first argument' refers to the initial input parameter of a predicate in the context of knowledge graph rules, specifically representing the subject argument in the argument embedding calculations.

Entity-classic_version.description: The 'classic version' refers to the original dataset or framework from which the authors adapted the Poker dataset to create a correct and complete knowledge graph for their experiments.

Entity-the_set_of_entity.description: The set of entities refers to the collection of identifiers for objects, such as places or people, that are represented within a knowledge graph (KG) as part of its structure, specifically denoted as E in the pair K = (E, F), where F represents the set of facts.

Entity-a_predicate_p.description: A predicate P refers to a relational function in a knowledge graph that connects entities through subject and object arguments, represented by an embedding matrix that captures the relationships between these entities.

Entity-fact_pk__ei__ej_.description: The entity mention 'fact Pk(ei, ej)' refers to a logical statement indicating the presence of a relationship defined by the predicate Pk between the entities ei and ej in the knowledge graph, represented as a binary value in an adjacency matrix.

Entity-hold-out_fact.label: hold-out facts
Entity-hold-out_fact.description: Hold-out facts refer to a subset of data that is reserved for evaluating the performance of a model or algorithm, specifically in the context of generating queries for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-a_set_of_entity.label: a set of entities
Entity-a_set_of_entity.description: A set of entities refers to a collection of entities that are relevant to a specific target predicate in a knowledge graph, which are identified and initialized for the purpose of mining open path rules.

Entity-yago2_core.label: YAGO2 core
Entity-yago2_core.description: YAGO2 core is a comprehensive knowledge base and semantic web resource that integrates structured information from various sources to facilitate data mining and knowledge representation.

Entity-poker.label: Poker

Entity-data-first_approach.label: data-first approach
Entity-data-first_approach.description: The 'data-first approach' refers to a methodology in knowledge graph construction that prioritizes the integration and modeling of large volumes of weakly-structured data with minimal structural constraints, allowing for flexible and dynamic information addition.

Entity-definition_4.label: Definition 4
Entity-definition_4.description: Definition 4 refers to the concept of argument embedding in a knowledge graph, which defines the argument embeddings of the subject and object arguments of a predicate as vectors based on the entities occurring as subjects and objects in the graph.

Entity-subject_argument_of_p___i1_.label: subject argument of P_{i+1}
Entity-subject_argument_of_p___i1_.description: The 'subject argument of P_{i+1}' refers to the entity that serves as the subject in the predicate P_{i+1} within the context of open path rules in knowledge graph completion, where it is involved in establishing relationships with other entities through a sequence of predicates.

Entity-twice_the_number_of_fact.label: twice the number of facts
Entity-twice_the_number_of_fact.description: The term 'twice the number of facts' refers to the theoretical upper limit on the number of distinct queries that can be generated from a set of facts in a knowledge graph, where each fact can potentially contribute to multiple queries.

Entity-distinct_entity.label: distinct entities
Entity-distinct_entity.description: In the context of knowledge graphs, 'distinct entities' refers to the unique elements within a set of entities that satisfy certain conditions or rules, as determined by the non-zero elements in a vector representation derived from an adjacency matrix.

Entity-vector__e_i_.description: The term 'vectors {e_i}' refers to the embeddings of entities in a knowledge graph, represented as vectors in a latent space, which are learned by the RESCAL model to capture the relationships and interactions among entities and predicates.

Entity-rule_language.description: The term 'rule language' refers to a formal language used in rule learning systems to express logical rules that can be applied for knowledge graph completion.

Entity-20_randomly_selected_predicate_fr.description: A subset of 20 predicates chosen at random from the FB15KSE dataset, which is used for knowledge graph completion and related tasks.

Entity-it_embedding_vector.description: The term 'its embedding vector' refers to the vector representation of an entity e in a knowledge graph, which is computed by averaging the embeddings of all entities associated with that entity in the graph.

Entity-logical_rule.label: logical rules

Entity-measure_support.label: measures support
Entity-measure_support.description: Measures support refers to a quantitative metric used in rule learning that counts the instances in a knowledge graph where both the body and head of a closed path rule are satisfied, thereby assessing the rule's effectiveness in explaining facts.

Entity-the_method.label: The method
Entity-the_method.description: The method refers to a process that initializes a set of entities relevant to a specific target predicate in a knowledge graph, facilitating the mining of high-quality Open Path rules.

Entity-head_of_the_rule.label: head of the rule
Entity-head_of_the_rule.description: The 'head of the rule' refers to the part of a rule in a knowledge graph that represents the conclusion or target fact that can be inferred from the conditions specified in the rule's body.

Entity-product.description: The term 'product' refers to the mathematical operation that combines predicate embeddings along a path in a knowledge graph to create a low-dimensional representation of the latent features connecting the endpoints of the path.

Entity-top-ranked.label: top-ranked
Entity-top-ranked.description: The term 'top-ranked' refers to the highest position in a sequence of answers provided by link predictors in the context of knowledge graph completion, indicating the most relevant entity among multiple ranked responses.

Entity-curating_task.label: curating task

Entity-the_plausibility_of_a_fact.label: the plausibility of a fact

Entity-precision_and_recall.label: precision and recall

Entity-unobserved_but_intrinsic_property.label: unobserved but intrinsic properties

Entity-vector_embeddings.label: vector embeddings

summary:
Enterprise and public Knowledge Graphs (KGs) are often incomplete, and while traditional rule-based methods learn closed rules, we introduce Open Path (OP) rules, which are existentially constrained. Our novel algorithm, OPRL, learns OP rules and generates relevant queries for KG completion, even in the absence of closed rules. To enhance scalability, we propose an embedding-based fitness function and efficient vector computation for assessing rule quality. Evaluations on Freebase, YAGO2, Wikidata, and a synthetic Poker KG show that OPRL can mine hundreds of accurate rules from KGs with up to 8 million facts, achieving query precision of 98% and recall of 62%, marking a significant advancement in active knowledge graph completion.

Knowledge Graphs (KGs) are effective for modeling large amounts of weakly-structured data, allowing flexible information addition unlike relational databases. However, KGs often lack comprehensive coverage of entities and relationships, similar to Wikipedia's uneven topic coverage. Techniques for KG completion and rule learning have been developed to automate curation, using models to predict missing facts. This paper introduces a novel approach to rule-based KG completion that identifies unknown unknowns by learning open path rules (OP) to generate open-ended questions instead of specific facts. OP rules can infer missing facts even when entities are absent from the KG, facilitating the introduction of new entities. The proposed method complements traditional link prediction by generating relevant queries needed for KG completion. The paper presents an algorithm, OPRL, for learning OP rules and demonstrates its effectiveness in generating queries that can help complete KGs. The structure of the paper includes foundational concepts, the OP rule formalism, the OPRL method, query generation, and related literature.

Rule-Based KG Completion involves entities as identifiers for objects and facts as RDF triples relating these entities. Knowledge graphs (KGs) consist of entities and facts. Rule learning systems like RLVLR and ScaleKB use closed path (CP) rules, which have a head and a body, to infer new facts from existing ones in the KG. The effectiveness of rules is measured by support, standard confidence (SC), and head coverage (HC). Representation learning methods model KGs for tasks like link prediction by embedding entities and predicates into a latent space. Two main types of embeddings are translation-based and compositional embeddings. RESCAL, a compositional-based learner, captures complex interactions among entities and predicates, making it suitable for mining operational rules due to its effective heuristic function.

In our active knowledge graph completion task, we mine open path (OP) rules, which take the form: P_t(x, z_0) ← P_1(z_0, z_1) ∧ P_2(z_1, z_2) ∧ ... ∧ P_n(z_{n-1}, y). OP rules differ from closed path (CP) rules as they can be linear and are more expressive, allowing instantiations not possible with CP rules. From an OP rule, we can only infer questions, not facts. For example, the rule citizenOf(x, t) ← livesIn(x, z) implies that if x lives in z, then x is a citizen of somewhere (t). To evaluate OP rules, we define open path standard confidence (OPSC) and open path head coverage (OPHC). The support degree of an OP rule is calculated based on the entities satisfying its body and head. For instance, for the rule P_1(x, z_0) ← P_2(z_0, z_1) ∧ P_3(z_1, y), if 3 entities satisfy the body and 5 satisfy the head, we find OPsupp = 3, OPSC = 3/7, and OPHC = 3/5.

The goal is to mine a Knowledge Graph (KG) for high-quality OP rules related to a target predicate P. We enhance the RLVLR architecture by introducing a novel fitness function to assess OP rule quality based on predicate embeddings and a vector computation method for evaluating these rules against large KGs. Our OP rule miner, OPRL, takes user-defined parameters for rule length and quality scores. We first reduce the KG size using a sampling algorithm to focus on entities relevant to P, creating a reduced KG K'. We compute embeddings for predicates and arguments to construct a fitness function that improves scalability. The PathFinding() method generates OP rules for P and its inverse, while IncPathFinding() extends top-ranked rules. We ensure no redundancy in mined rules and evaluate them using OPSC and OPHC metrics, employing efficient matrix and vector multiplication for scalability.

To manage potential rules in PathFinding(), we filter low-quality candidates using two fitness functions: co-occurrence and open path, based on embedding representations. The co-occurrence function evaluates predicates by shared entities, while the open path function connects them through predicate chains. CP rules are simpler to compute than OP rules due to fewer variables. Argument embeddings are averaged from subject and object entities. Co-occurrence fitness for OP rules is defined through local pairwise functions, and open path fitness uses the product of predicate embeddings. Both functions are complementary, and a hybrid approach selects the top candidate rules.

The Evaluation() method in Algorithm 1 assesses candidate rules from a sampled KG for efficiency, selecting those with OPsupp(r) ≥ 1 and filtering out obsolete rules using OPSC and OPHC metrics. The KG is represented as square adjacency matrices for efficient computation, checking satisfiability of body atoms to identify KG facts that trigger rules. Minimum thresholds for OPSC and OPHC are set at runtime, discarding non-compliant rules. The method introduces components for mining OP rules, including function-free Horn rules and a rapid rule quality estimation method.

We can mine OP rules from KGs to generate queries for Active Knowledge Graph Completion (AKGC). The task involves creating queries like P(?, e') and P(e, ?) using predicate P. An inference module derives these queries from KG facts and OP rules learned via OPRL, with the confidence degree (CD) defined as the maximum OPSC of the inducing rules. The challenge in industrial applications is generating valuable queries without hold-out facts. For AKGC, we use OP rules over training data to induce relevant queries across the knowledge base, focusing on mining OP rules to predict queries rather than relying solely on link predictors.

We conducted experiments to evaluate OPRL, focusing on generating relevant questions for knowledge graph completion rather than answering them. Our approach assumes a perfect link predictor to assess question relevancy based on test facts. As the first method to automatically generate relevant questions, we compared OPRL against two baselines: a probabilistic query generator and a modified rule-based link predictor. Our findings show that OPRL effectively mines quality OP rules from various KGs, demonstrating superior recall and precision in generated queries compared to the baselines. We tested our system on four benchmark datasets, including FB15K SELECTED and YAGO2 core, and utilized a synthetic poker dataset for experiments. All tests were performed on a high-performance server, with specific parameters set for rule mining and embeddings.

The study evaluates the effectiveness of OPRL in discovering high-quality rules, comparing its performance with proposed fitness functions. Rule quality is assessed using OPSC/OPHC scores against full benchmark KGs. For query evaluation, hold-out facts are needed; FB15KSE has available test and training sets, while Poker and YAGO2 core data is randomly split 90% for training and 10% for testing. Table 2 presents the average number of quality rules mined across predicates, with Wikidata being an exception. OPRL successfully learns plausible rules from large KGs in under two hours. Examples of mined rules from Wikidata illustrate their utility. An experiment using random predicates from FB15KSE indicates that a hybrid fitness function outperforms individual functions in mining quality rules.

The experiments evaluate the relevance of queries generated from OPRL-mined rules, considering a query relevant if it has an answer in the test set. Three baseline query sets, Prand, were created for comparison. OPRL outperformed Prand on FB15KSE, YAGO2 core, and Poker by factors of approximately 6, 2, and 9, respectively. YAGO2's weaker performance is attributed to fewer repeatable patterns and potentially more missing facts. In synthetic Poker, high precision and recall were observed, indicating relevant queries were generated. The sensitivity of OPRL performance to the OPSC threshold was analyzed, revealing a drop in recall and an anomaly at OPSC 0.9 due to FB15KSE's incompleteness. OPRL was compared to RLvLR, a state-of-the-art link predictor, by translating RLvLR-generated facts into queries. Adjustments to RLvLR's aggregation method improved its performance, but OPRL still showed superior query generation, with a partial AUC of 0.30 compared to RLvLR's 0.23.

Previous work in rule learning from knowledge graphs primarily focuses on Closed rules, which are less expressive than our OP rules. While OP rule learners generate new facts, our goal is to create relevant queries for these facts. There have been initial efforts to learn existential rules from knowledge graphs, but no learning system has been proposed. We have not found any prior methods that generate relevant queries for link predictors in knowledge graph completion. CHAI filters facts to enhance prediction by focusing on probable facts, but it does not generate queries like OPRL and relies heavily on the initial set of facts.

In this paper, we proposed a method for learning rules with free variables from Knowledge Graphs (KGs). Such rules can be used to generate queries soliciting missing facts. Notably, the queries could be fed to link predictors, enabling a fully automated framework for KG completion.

We introduced the following novel components: (1) We propose OP rules, a fragment of function-free Horn rules, which allows us to mine rules with free variables while keeping the complexity of the learning phase manageable. (2) We introduced a novel method to estimate the quality of each candidate rule based on its embedding representation. (3) We proposed an efficient method to evaluate OP rules by exactly computing the quality of each rule using matrix and vector operations. (4) We showed how OP rules can be used to generate highly relevant queries for missing links, introducing the first work on active knowledge graph completion.

Our experiments show that OPRL can learn rules for KGs with varying sizes and degrees of incompleteness. We demonstrate the usefulness of the mined rules by applying them to three different KGs to infer relevant queries.

Our proposed method outperforms the baselines and shows its strength, especially in the complete KG, Poker, with 0.98 precision.

There remain some intriguing challenges for future work. We plan to extend OPRL to learn rules with more complex shapes, such as stars, and with numerical attributes. We plan to pair OPRL with a link predictor to form a unified framework for fully automated KG completion. We will also trial OPRL in a setting for human-curated maintenance on an enterprise KG.

Predicate-are_known_to_be.label: are known to be
Predicate-are_known_to_be.description: The predicate 'are known to be' serves to establish a recognized or accepted relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject possesses a certain quality, characteristic, or state that is acknowledged by a broader audience or community. It implies a consensus or common understanding regarding the nature of the subject as it relates to the object.

Predicate-scale.label: scale
Predicate-scale.description: The predicate 'scale' indicates the ability of the subject to increase or decrease in size, capacity, or effectiveness in relation to the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject can adapt or perform efficiently at varying levels or volumes, as represented by the object.

Predicate-learn.label: learn
Predicate-learn.description: The predicate 'learn' signifies the process by which the subject acquires knowledge, skills, or understanding related to the object. In this context, it indicates that the subject engages in an activity or method that enables it to comprehend, internalize, or adapt to the characteristics or principles of the object.

Predicate-are_constrained.label: are constrained
Predicate-are_constrained.description: The predicate 'are constrained' indicates a relationship where the subject is limited or restricted in some way by the object. It suggests that the characteristics, behaviors, or functionalities of the subject are subject to certain conditions or rules defined by the object, thereby establishing a dependency or influence between the two entities.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' serves as a linking verb that establishes a relationship of identity or classification between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is defined or characterized by the object, suggesting that the subject belongs to a category or possesses the qualities described by the object.

Predicate-is_for.label: is for
Predicate-is_for.description: The predicate 'is for' establishes a relationship of purpose or intended use between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is designed, intended, or suitable for the action, process, or concept represented by the object. This connection implies that the subject serves a specific function or goal related to the object.

Predicate-complete.label: complete
Predicate-complete.description: The predicate 'complete' indicates that the subject possesses all necessary elements or fulfills all requirements in relation to the object. In this context, it suggests that the subject, which can be a set of rules or a framework, fully encompasses or adequately addresses all aspects or components of the object, which may refer to knowledge graphs or similar entities. This relationship implies a state of wholeness or sufficiency in the connection between the subject and the object.

Predicate-answer.label: answer
Predicate-answer.description: The predicate 'answer' denotes a relationship where the subject provides a response or solution to the inquiries or requests represented by the object. It implies an interaction where the subject is capable of addressing the needs or questions posed by the object, thereby facilitating understanding or resolution.

Predicate-derived_from.label: derived from
Predicate-derived_from.description: The predicate 'derived from' indicates a relationship where the subject is produced, generated, or obtained as a result of the object. It signifies that the subject has its origins or source in the object, implying a dependency or connection where the characteristics, properties, or content of the subject can be traced back to the object.

Predicate-in.label: in
Predicate-in.description: The predicate 'in' indicates a relationship of inclusion or containment, where the subject is situated within or is part of the context or environment represented by the object. It signifies that the subject exists or operates within the boundaries or framework defined by the object.

Predicate-are_derived_from.label: are derived from
Predicate-are_derived_from.description: The predicate 'are derived from' indicates a relationship where the subject is produced, generated, or obtained as a result of the object. It implies that the subject has its origins or source in the object, suggesting a dependency or a foundational connection between the two entities.

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: The predicate 'generate' indicates the action of producing or creating something as a result of a process or set of conditions defined by the subject. In this context, it connects the subject, which represents the source or mechanism (such as rules, algorithms, or systems), to the object, which represents the outcome or product (such as queries, data, or results). This relationship highlights the transformative effect of the subject on the object, where the subject's properties or functions lead to the emergence of the object.

Predicate-for.label: for
Predicate-for.description: The predicate 'for' indicates a purpose, function, or intended use of the subject in relation to the object. It establishes a connection where the subject serves as a means or context that facilitates, supports, or is relevant to the object.

Predicate-generates.label: generates
Predicate-generates.description: The predicate 'generates' indicates a relationship in which the subject produces, creates, or brings about the object. It implies an active process where the subject is responsible for the existence or formation of the object, suggesting a causal or functional connection between the two.

Predicate-are_answered_by.label: are answered by
Predicate-are_answered_by.description: The predicate 'are answered by' indicates a relationship where the subject is receiving a response or solution from the object. It implies that the object provides the necessary information, clarification, or resolution to the inquiries or requests represented by the subject.

Predicate-is_a.label: is a
Predicate-is_a.description: The predicate 'is a' establishes a classification or categorization relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject belongs to or is a member of the category defined by the object. It signifies that the subject possesses the characteristics or qualities associated with the object, thereby linking them in a hierarchical or definitional manner.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or equivalence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject possesses a certain quality, characteristic, or state that is represented by the object, effectively asserting that both the subject and object refer to the same entity or concept in a particular context.

Predicate-scales_well_with.label: scales well with
Predicate-scales_well_with.description: The predicate 'scales well with' indicates a positive relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that as the subject increases in size, complexity, or usage, the object maintains or improves its effectiveness, efficiency, or performance.
